briefOverview: The revelation blesses those gathering to Zion and sets out core commandments emphasizing love, gratitude, Sabbath worship, and wise use of the earth. It promises present peace and eternal life to the righteous.
summary: The Lord blesses those who come to the land of Zion with an eye single to His glory and promises rest to the dead and a crown in the Father’s mansions. The faithful will receive earthly good things and further commandments and revelations. God reiterates the great commandments to love Him and one’s neighbor and forbids theft, adultery, murder, and related sins, calling for gratitude in all things and a sacrifice of a broken heart and contrite spirit. To remain unspotted from the world, disciples are to keep the Lord’s day holy by resting from labors, offering sacraments and oblations, confessing sins, and approaching the day with fasting, rejoicing, prayer, and a cheerful heart—avoiding excess levity. If they do so, the fullness of the earth is theirs: its beasts, plants, and goods, made to please the eye and gladden the heart, to be used with judgment, not excess nor extortion. God is offended chiefly by those who do not acknowledge His hand and who disobey His commandments. Those who do righteousness obtain peace in this world and eternal life in the next.
externalContext: This section was received by Joseph Smith in early August 1831 in Jackson County, Missouri, shortly after the site for the city of Zion and a temple location were designated for the Latter-day Saints. Converts were beginning to migrate to this frontier area, where agrarian life framed daily concerns about labor, land, and provisions—reflected in the revelation’s attention to the earth’s bounty and its wise use. Historical accounts place the revelation on the day of Polly Knight’s burial (Aug. 7, 1831), offering comfort about the blessed state of the faithful dead. The instruction on Sabbath observance also helped standardize worship patterns among early Saints in a new, developing community.
externalReferences: The command to love God and neighbor echoes the biblical “great commandments” (Deuteronomy 6:5; Leviticus 19:18), summarized by Jesus as the heart of “the law and the prophets” (Matthew 22:37–40), language mirrored in verse 22. The promise that those who die “rest from their labors” and that “their works shall follow them” closely parallels Revelation 14:13, while the image of “mansions” recalls John 14:2. The Sabbath emphasis aligns with the fourth commandment (Exodus 20:8–11) and Isaiah’s counsel to honor the holy day (Isaiah 58:13–14). The “sacrifice … of a broken heart and a contrite spirit” resonates with Psalm 51:17.
practicalQuestions: How will I keep the Lord’s day holy in a way that invites rejoicing, prayer, and genuine rest?
Where can I show more consistent gratitude by “confessing [God’s] hand in all things”?
What changes can I make to use material resources with judgment—avoiding excess and exploitation?
What does offering a broken heart and contrite spirit look like in my current circumstances?
How can I cultivate cheerful devotion without slipping into frivolity or irreverence?
uncertainAreas: “Not with much laughter, for this is sin” (v. 15) is ambiguous; it seems to warn against frivolity, balanced by calls to joy and cheerfulness. The specific referent of “trouble me no more concerning this matter” (v. 22) is unclear—likely concluding the preceding instructions. The text assumes a “Lord’s day” without naming which weekday; historically this was Sunday among early Saints. The scope of “the fulness of the earth is yours” is broad; its limits are qualified by “with judgment, not to excess, neither by extortion,” but practical boundaries are not specified.
